body:
Thanks for the report. This isn't a bug, the rule is working as intended, as noted in the docs:

> This rule checks computed properties which have a simple name as well.
> Simple names are names which are expressed by an Identifier node or a Literal node.

So I think the only question here is whether or not we want to add an option to ignored all computed keys.

@eslint/eslint-team thoughts?

I think we can treat this as a design bug because, as explained in the original post, order can matter when using computed keys. An option seems like a good idea to address this while retaining the current default behavior.
Also, for the same reasons, when the option is enabled, I think the sort should reset when a computed key is encountered. The same as it currently does when a spread is encountered.

> Maybe `ignoreComputedKeys`?

Sounds good to me. I can work on this.

issue.title: feat: Add `ignoreComputedKeys` option in `sort-keys` rule

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion

labels.name: feature
labels.description: This change adds a new feature to ESLint

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.
